narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: Weekly virtual language table
The class was synchronous 3 days and asynchronous 2 days
NA
Watching videos.

In addition to virtual seminar, we also did virtual "language tables" every week. These were small meetings over Zoom where we would have informal discussions in Persian with the TA. Or the TA would teach us new vocabulary.

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I developed a foundational understanding of Persian and by the end of the semester was able to speak fluidly for 4 minutes in Persian
We learned to read, write, speak, and listen to the Persian language. We also learned lots of cultural elements like art, food, and literature.
I learned persian at a very fast pace. This course teaches you more persian than any other beginning language class teaches you another language.

I learned so much about Persian language and culture! We learned the alphabet and small words along the way, then worked our way up to sentences and verbs in multiple tenses. Ostad (professor) does so well to teach us the proper accent as well, and we did several discussions on the literature, cities, and art of Iran.
Improve my ability to read, speak, and write in Persian.
I gained skills in Persian writing and conversation as well as insight into Persian culture.

I learned how to speak, read, and write elementary Persian. That includes vocabulary related to school, the home, greetings, cooking, studying, time/day/year, numbers, weather, sports, television, professions, descriptive adjectives, etc. We also learned the present, past, and simple future tenses, as well as other grammar rules. I also learned a ton about Persian culture and history, including art forms, famous writers, movies, music, geography, etc.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Great course that doesn't need improvements

Ostad's individualized attention made it easy to ask questions and learn. Also, she created a low-stress environment where we could learn through trying and making mistakes.

One flaw was the lack of clear grading. I think it would be nice to know where we stand in the class grade-wise so that we can adjust our work and do the best we can.
The class is very strong. The only weakness I can think of is sometimes we didn't have enough to do everything in class, but that's a very minor weakness.
I don't think this course has any weaknesses, honestly. Ostad was very attentive and worked with each of us to improve our skills.
I wish for more discussions about our homework.

The professor is very kind, encouraging, and focused on in-class participation so students have ample opportunity to practice their skills. 

The modes of learning and practicing begin to feel repetitive after awhile. I also think the course could move along more quickly, perhaps by introducing more vocabulary/letters of the alphabet/basic grammar rules at one time.
This is a fantastic course. I don't think it has any weaknesses. The workload is manageable. You will learn a lot of the language and a lot about Persian culture.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Professor Shayesteh was successful in transferring her class online. I was really impressed as to how this class could be done so well over zoom.
It was my best class in the pandemic in terms of engagement and improvement
The seminar format helped to make class engaging, but I think that using zoom breakout rooms would allow more people to speak at once.

This class was taught through Zoom due to COVID-19. But Ostad was still able to show us the proper way to write letters through Zoom, and we were still able to practice with partners through breakout rooms. While in-person learning would have been awesome, I think we did the best we could considering the circumstances.
Overall it's good and effective.

I really appreciate that the professor assigned work to be done independently in lieu of Zoom meetings for two class periods of the week. I think that break from Zoom really allowed for better engagement on the days we did meet synchronously.

The professor did an amazing job of teaching us and evaluating us fully virtually. She used a whiteboard (both physically and virtually) to teach us how to write. She evaluated our writing by having us hold things up to the camera, and by annotating photos of our submitted assignments. She used breakout rooms to facilitate conversation among students. And she ensured that every student got the chance to read, write, speak aloud, etc. during class. She is great.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely.
Yes, very helpful for learning a new language like Persian
Absolutely. Ostad is an amazing teacher and the class is so much fun and moves at a slower pace. It was my favorite class of the semester.
Yes, if you want to learn persian

I would recommend this course. Ostad is an excellent professor, and Persian is a terrific language especially at Yale due to the small class size. And for national security/political science people interested in Iran and its geopolitics, learning Persian could be very helpful after graduation.
Yes I will, if you want to study Persian.

I would recommend to any student who is genuinely interested in learning Persian and about Iranian culture. I don't think the course is engaging enough to provide a valuable experience for students who don't already have a certain level of self-motivation to learn Persian but it is enjoyable for someone who is genuinely interested.

I would 100% recommend this class. I have taken SO many language classes in many languages over the course of my life and this was by far one of the best. I learned so much, even during a global pandemic.
